oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Control carrot fly
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: van den Broek, Rob
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Environmental aspects
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The larva of the carrot fly, Psila rosae, may in some umbelliferous plants cause significant damage. The insect is mainly in the temperate regions of the northern hemisphere, but also in some subtropical areas. Everywhere in the Netherlands where carrots are grown, is degradation. In the Netherlands organic growers seem well with the carrot fly problem to go, the number of reports of harm and disapproval is not too bad. With smart cultivation measures, the problems are manageable and, understanding the biology and life cycle of the carrot fly, appropriate measures may limit the damage. In this bioKennis report an overview and tips.
oai_dc:dc.dc:identifier: van den Broek, Rob (2011) Control carrot fly. bioKennis, Wageningen.
